p: We examined the distribution of regional average concentrations as a function of air pollution level in Fig 6. The number of hours with pollution at the highest levels increases due to climate change alone, and further rises given greater emissions of NO X and SO 2 associated with higher climate-induced electricity demand. For PM 2.5, the minimum regional average concentration simulated under a future climate (4.37 μg/m 3 for MCCO) is above the average value for present-day (4.26 μg/m 3). Present-day values range from a minimum of 2.91 μg/m 3 to a maximum 5.98 μg/m 3. The highest regional average concentrations modeled under a future climate (8.75 μg/m 3 for MCCO) are higher than we see at any time in the present-day simulation. The additional consideration of adaptation through air conditioning use further increases the minimum and maximum values to 4.48 μg/m 3 and 8.87 μg/m 3, respectively.
